title: Hockey Vocabulary
description: Lace up your skates and test your knowledge of ice hockey terms!

questions.question: In hockey, what is a 'hat trick'?
options: Three penalties in one period
Winning three faceoffs in a row
A goalie saving three consecutive shots
One player scoring three goals in a single game
questions.explanation: A hat trick is when a single player scores three goals in one game. Fans traditionally celebrate by throwing hats onto the ice.

questions.question: What is a 'power play' in hockey?
options: When a team has a numerical advantage because the opponent has a player in the penalty box
A play involving all five skaters
A strong offensive push
An extra period of play
questions.explanation: A power play occurs when one team has more players on the ice because the opposing team has one or more players serving a penalty in the penalty box.

questions.question: In hockey, what is 'icing'?
options: A celebration involving ice
Applying ice to injuries
Shooting the puck from behind center ice across the opposing goal line without it being touched
Freezing the puck against the boards
questions.explanation: Icing is called when a player shoots the puck from behind the center red line all the way across the opposing team's goal line without it being touched, resulting in a faceoff in the offending team's zone.

questions.question: What is a 'shutout' in hockey?
options: A game in which the goaltender allows no goals
A game that goes to a shootout
Preventing the other team from taking any shots
Being eliminated from the playoffs
questions.explanation: A shutout occurs when a goaltender prevents the opposing team from scoring any goals for the entire game, one of the most valued achievements for a goalie.

questions.question: In hockey, what does 'five-hole' refer to?
options: Five players shooting in a shootout
The space between a goalie's legs
Five holes in the net
A penalty lasting five minutes
questions.explanation: The five-hole is the space between a goaltender's legs. Goalies have five 'holes': above each shoulder (1 and 2), below each arm (3 and 4), and between the legs (5).

questions.question: What is a 'Zamboni' in hockey?
options: A type of hockey stick
An Italian-style goal celebration
A machine that resurfaces the ice between periods
A defensive formation
questions.explanation: A Zamboni is the brand name (now used generically) for the ice resurfacing machine that shaves, cleans, and applies a fresh layer of water to the ice surface between periods.

questions.question: In hockey, what is a 'slap shot'?
options: Slapping an opponent with a glove
A shot taken after falling on the ice
A powerful shot where the player winds up and strikes the puck with a full swing
A wrist shot taken while skating
questions.explanation: A slap shot is the hardest shot in hockey, where the player raises the stick behind the body and swings down forcefully, hitting the ice just behind the puck for maximum power.

questions.question: What does 'offside' mean in hockey?
options: Standing behind the goal
Playing on the wrong team's bench
An attacking player entering the offensive zone before the puck
Crossing the center red line too early
questions.explanation: Offside is called when an attacking player crosses the blue line into the offensive zone before the puck does, resulting in a faceoff outside the zone.

questions.question: In hockey, what is a 'breakaway'?
options: When the ice breaks
A broken hockey stick
A fight that breaks out during play
A player skating alone toward the opposing goalie with no defenders between them
questions.explanation: A breakaway occurs when a player has possession of the puck and is skating toward the opposing goal with no defenders between them and the goaltender.

questions.question: What is a 'deke' in hockey?
options: A deceptive move to fake out an opponent
A designated shooter in a shootout
A defensive zone clearance
A type of penalty
questions.explanation: A deke (short for 'decoy') is a deceptive move made by a puck carrier to fake out a defender or goaltender, often involving quick stickhandling or body fakes.

questions.question: In hockey, what is 'boarding'?
options: Skating along the boards
Getting on the team roster
A penalty for leaving the bench
Violently checking an opponent into the boards
questions.explanation: Boarding is a penalty called when a player pushes, checks, or trips an opponent causing them to be thrown violently into the boards surrounding the rink.

questions.question: What is the 'crease' in hockey?
options: The bench area
The painted area in front of the goal where the goaltender operates
A wrinkle in the ice surface
The center ice circle
questions.explanation: The crease is the semi-circular area painted in front of each goal, designated as the goaltender's territory. Specific rules govern player contact with the goalie in this area.

questions.question: In hockey, what is a 'Gordie Howe hat trick'?
options: A goal, an assist, and a fight in the same game
Three hat tricks in a season
Three goals from center ice
Three goals in the third period
questions.explanation: A Gordie Howe hat trick is an unofficial achievement of scoring a goal, recording an assist, and getting into a fight all in the same game, named after the legendary tough and skilled player.

questions.question: What is 'hooking' in hockey?
options: Using the stick blade to impede an opponent's progress
Scoring with a curved shot
A type of pass
Pulling the goalie
questions.explanation: Hooking is a penalty called when a player uses the blade of their stick to restrain or impede an opponent's movement or progress.

questions.question: In hockey, what does 'pulling the goalie' mean?
options: The goalie pulling a muscle
Removing the goalie from the team
Replacing the goaltender with an extra skater for a numerical advantage
Dragging the goalie off the ice after a fight
questions.explanation: Pulling the goalie is a strategy where a team removes their goaltender and replaces them with an extra attacker, typically used when trailing late in a game to gain a scoring advantage.
